content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. The hydrocarbon cyclobutane, <math alttext="C 4 H 8"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, is represented above. At high temperatures, cyclobutane quickly decomposes into ethene, <math alttext="C 2 H 4"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Draw a Lewis electron-dot diagram of the ethene molecule in the following box.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. The hydrocarbon cyclobutane, <math alttext="C 4 H 8"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, is represented above. At high temperatures, cyclobutane quickly decomposes into ethene, <math alttext="C 2 H 4"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Draw a Lewis electron-dot diagram of the ethene molecule in the following box.
(b) Estimate the value of the <math alttext="H C H"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond angle in ethene.

(c) The graph below shows the concentration of cyclobutane as it decomposes over time at <math alttext="1270 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1270</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (i) Based on the graph, determine the order of the decomposition reaction of cyclobutane at <math alttext="1270 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1270</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.

(ii) Calculate the time, in milliseconds, that it would take for 99 percent of the original cyclobutane at <math alttext="1270 Kelvin"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1270</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to decompose.

Another alkane with a ring structure is cyclopentane, <math alttext="C 5 H 10 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>10</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Cyclopentane reacts with chlorine, <math alttext="C l 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, to produce <math alttext="C 2 H 9 C l gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>9</mtext></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H C l gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Following is a representation of a proposed mechanism for the reaction.<math alttext="C l 2 reacts to produce 2 C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>(slow)<math alttext="C l, plus C 5 H 10, react to produce H C l, plus C 5 H 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>+</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><mtext>HCl</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>+</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>(fast)<math alttext="C 5 H 9, plus C l, react to produce C 5 H 9 C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>(fast)
(d) Write a rate law for the reaction that is consistent with the mechanism. Justify your answer.

(e) A student claims that <math alttext="C l 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is a catalyst in the reaction. Explain why the student’s claim is false.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
